metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: PHP Filters
Validating data = Determine if the data is in proper form.
content.html: Validating data = Determine if the data is in proper form.

content.text: Sanitizing data = Remove any illegal character from the data.
content.html: Sanitizing data = Remove any illegal character from the data.

content.text: The PHP Filter Extension
PHP filters are used to validate and sanitize external input.
content.html: PHP filters are used to validate and sanitize external input.

content.text: The PHP filter extension has many of the functions needed for checking user input, and is designed to make data validation easier and quicker.
content.html: The PHP filter extension has many of the functions needed for checking user input, and is designed to make data validation easier and quicker.

content.text: The filter_list() function can be used to list what the PHP filter extension offers:
content.html: The filter_list() function can be used to list what the PHP filter extension offers:

content.code:
$filter) { echo '';  }  ?>
Filter NameFilter ID
' . $filter . '' . filter_id($filter) . '
content.code_html:
<table>
  <tr>
    <td>Filter Name</td>
    <td>Filter ID</td>
  </tr>
  <?php
  foreach (filter_list() as $id =>$filter) {
    echo '<tr><td>' . $filter . '</td><td>' . filter_id($filter) . '</td></tr>';
  }
  ?>
</table>

content.text: Why Use Filters?
Many web applications receive external input. External input/data can be:
content.html: Many web applications receive external input. External input/data can be:

content.text: You should always validate external data! Invalid submitted data can lead to security problems and break your webpage! By using PHP filters you can be sure your application gets the correct input!
content.html:
You should always validate external data!
Invalid submitted data can lead to security problems and break your webpage!
By using PHP filters you can be sure your application gets the correct input!

content.text: PHP filter_var() Function
The filter_var() function both validate and sanitize data.
content.html: The filter_var() function both validate and sanitize data.

content.text: The filter_var() function filters a single variable with a specified filter. It takes two pieces of data:
content.html: The filter_var() function filters a single variable with a specified filter. It takes two pieces of data:

content.text: Sanitize a String
The following example uses the filter_var() function to remove all HTML tags from a string:
content.html: The following example uses the filter_var() function to remove all HTML tags from a string:

content.code_html:
<?php
$str = "<h1>Hello World!</h1>";
$newstr = filter_var($str, FILTER_SANITIZE_STRING);
echo $newstr;
?>

content.text: Validate an Integer

The following example uses the filter_var() function to check if the variable $int is an integer. If $int is an integer, the output of the code below will be: "Integer is valid". If $int is not an integer, the output will be: "Integer is not valid":
content.html: The following example uses the filter_var() function to check if the variable $int is an integer. If $int is an integer, the output of the code below will be: "Integer is valid". If $int is not an integer, the output will be: "Integer is not valid":

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?php$int = 100;if (!filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
    echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

content.code:
<?php$int = 100;if (!filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?php$int = 100;if (!filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
    echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
$int = 100;

if (!filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
  echo("Integer is valid");
} else {
  echo("Integer is not valid");
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?php$int = 100;if (!filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
    echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

content.text: Tip: filter_var() and Problem With 0
In the example above, if $int was set to 0, the function above will return "Integer is not valid". To solve this problem, use the code below:
content.html: In the example above, if $int was set to 0, the function above will return "Integer is not valid". To solve this problem, use the code below:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?php$int = 0;if (filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === 0 || !filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
    echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

content.code:
<?php$int = 0;if (filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === 0 || !filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?php$int = 0;if (filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === 0 || !filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
    echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
$int = 0;

if (filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === 0 || !filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
  echo("Integer is valid");
} else {
  echo("Integer is not valid");
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?php$int = 0;if (filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === 0 || !filter_var($int, FILTER_VALIDATE_INT) === false) {
    echo("Integer is valid");} else {  echo("Integer is not valid");}?>

content.text: Validate an IP Address
The following example uses the filter_var() function to check if the variable $ip is a valid IP address:
content.html: The following example uses the filter_var() function to check if the variable $ip is a valid IP address:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?php$ip = "127.0.0.1";if (!filter_var($ip, FILTER_VALIDATE_IP) === false) {
    echo("$ip is a valid IP address");} else {  echo("$ip is not a valid IP address");}?>
"$ip is not a valid IP address"

content.code:
<?php$ip = "127.0.0.1";if (!filter_var($ip, FILTER_VALIDATE_IP) === false) {
echo("$ip is a valid IP address");} else {  echo("$ip is not a valid IP address");}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?php$ip = "127.0.0.1";if (!filter_var($ip, FILTER_VALIDATE_IP) === false) {
    echo("$ip is a valid IP address");} else {  echo("$ip is not a valid IP address");}?>
"$ip is not a valid IP address"

content.code_html:
<?php
$ip = "127.0.0.1";

if (!filter_var($ip, FILTER_VALIDATE_IP) === false) {
  echo("$ip is a valid IP address");
} else {
  echo("$ip is not a valid IP address");
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?php$ip = "127.0.0.1";if (!filter_var($ip, FILTER_VALIDATE_IP) === false) {
    echo("$ip is a valid IP address");} else {  echo("$ip is not a valid IP address");}?>
"$ip is not a valid IP address"

content.text: Sanitize and Validate an Email Address
The following example uses the filter_var() function to first remove all illegal characters from the $email variable, then check if it is a valid email address:
content.html: The following example uses the filter_var() function to first remove all illegal characters from the $email variable, then check if it is a valid email address:

syntaxHighlighting.text: <?php$email = "john.doe@example.com";// Remove all illegal characters from email$email = filter_var($email, FILTER_SANITIZE_EMAIL);// Validate e-mailif (!filter_var($email, FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL) === false) {  echo("$email is a valid email address");} else {  echo("$email is not a valid email address");}?>
// Remove all illegal characters from email
"$email is not a valid email address"

content.code: <?php$email = "john.doe@example.com";// Remove all illegal characters from email$email = filter_var($email, FILTER_SANITIZE_EMAIL);// Validate e-mailif (!filter_var($email, FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL) === false) {  echo("$email is a valid email address");} else {  echo("$email is not a valid email address");}?>

syntax_highlighting.text: <?php$email = "john.doe@example.com";// Remove all illegal characters from email$email = filter_var($email, FILTER_SANITIZE_EMAIL);// Validate e-mailif (!filter_var($email, FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL) === false) {  echo("$email is a valid email address");} else {  echo("$email is not a valid email address");}?>
// Remove all illegal characters from email
"$email is not a valid email address"

content.code_html:
<?php
$email = "john.doe@example.com";

// Remove all illegal characters from email
$email = filter_var($email, FILTER_SANITIZE_EMAIL);

// Validate e-mail
if (!filter_var($email, FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL) === false) {
  echo("$email is a valid email address");
} else {
  echo("$email is not a valid email address");
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: <?php$email = "john.doe@example.com";// Remove all illegal characters from email$email = filter_var($email, FILTER_SANITIZE_EMAIL);// Validate e-mailif (!filter_var($email, FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL) === false) {  echo("$email is a valid email address");} else {  echo("$email is not a valid email address");}?>
// Remove all illegal characters from email
"$email is not a valid email address"

content.text: Sanitize and Validate a URL
The following example uses the filter_var() function to first remove all illegal characters from a URL, then check if $url is a valid URL:
content.html: The following example uses the filter_var() function to first remove all illegal characters from a URL, then check if $url is a valid URL:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?php$url = "https://www.w3schools.com";
 // Remove all illegal characters from a url$url = filter_var($url, FILTER_SANITIZE_URL);// Validate urlif (!filter_var($url, FILTER_VALIDATE_URL) === false) {  echo("$url is a valid URL");} else {  echo("$url is not a valid URL");}?>
// Remove all illegal characters from a url

content.code:
<?php$url = "https://www.w3schools.com";
// Remove all illegal characters from a url$url = filter_var($url, FILTER_SANITIZE_URL);// Validate urlif (!filter_var($url, FILTER_VALIDATE_URL) === false) {  echo("$url is a valid URL");} else {  echo("$url is not a valid URL");}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?php$url = "https://www.w3schools.com";
 // Remove all illegal characters from a url$url = filter_var($url, FILTER_SANITIZE_URL);// Validate urlif (!filter_var($url, FILTER_VALIDATE_URL) === false) {  echo("$url is a valid URL");} else {  echo("$url is not a valid URL");}?>
// Remove all illegal characters from a url

content.code_html:
<?php
$url = "https://www.w3schools.com";

// Remove all illegal characters from a url
$url = filter_var($url, FILTER_SANITIZE_URL);

// Validate url
if (!filter_var($url, FILTER_VALIDATE_URL) === false) {
  echo("$url is a valid URL");
} else {
  echo("$url is not a valid URL");
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?php$url = "https://www.w3schools.com";
 // Remove all illegal characters from a url$url = filter_var($url, FILTER_SANITIZE_URL);// Validate urlif (!filter_var($url, FILTER_VALIDATE_URL) === false) {  echo("$url is a valid URL");} else {  echo("$url is not a valid URL");}?>
// Remove all illegal characters from a url

content.text: Complete PHP Filter Reference
For a complete reference of all filter functions, go to our complete PHP Filter Reference. Check each filter to see what options and flags are available.
content.html: For a complete reference of all filter functions, go to our complete PHP Filter Reference. Check each filter to see what options and flags are available.

content.text: The reference contains a brief description, and examples of use, for each function!
content.html: The reference contains a brief description, and examples of use, for each function!
